attributes.title: Influence of Moral versus Authoritarian Message Framing in times of the COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.description: Building on the results of Everett, Colombatto, Chitus, Brady and Crockett (2020), see https://psyarxiv.com/9yqs8), we investigate the effect of moral versus authoritarian message-framing on social distancing behavior during Covid-19 restrictions in Germany.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Effects of leadership status and moral versus authoritarian message framing in tweets on social distancing during the Corona-19 pandemic

Building on the results of Everett, Colombatto, Chitus, Brady and Crockett (2020), see https://psyarxiv.com/9yqs8), we investigate the effect of moral versus authoritarian message-framing on social distancing behavior during Covid-19 restrictions in Germany.

other.value: Since we don't know much about the psychometric properties of the 22 questions used to measure autonomy, we will revise these items depending on response rates and factor loads, and then rerun the correlative analyses described above using only the selected subset of items.

sample.value: We will collect a minimum of 100 participants in each condition, 600 participants in total.

analyses.value:
1. We will conduct an ANOVA on the average responses to all 6 questions. This will be a 2 (pre-post) x 2 (author) x 3 (message framing) factorial design. Should there be no significant group differences at p=.10 (or lower) in the pre-intervention measurement, we will use a 2 (author) x 3 (message) design on the pre-post difference measure. 
2. We will correlate the 22 trait autonomy questions with the pre-post difference in all 6 groups. Additionally, we will analyze the pre-post difference by multiple regression analyses using trait autonomy and authoritarian treatment (leadership status and message framing) ) as a predictor. We will subsequently enter control variables (e.g., numbers of children, positive COVID testing etc.), if these show sufficient variance. 
3. To rule out floor/ceiling effects (response rates below .20 or above .80), we will repeat the analyses using only items with response rates between .20 and .80 (averaged across all groups).

outliers.value: We will use data of participants who have completed the entire survey and answered all control questions (two attention checks) correctly. Only participants who are 18 years or older can participate in the study.

dependent.value: We will ask seven questions about social distancing behaviors in accord with governmental regulations and recommendations in Germany, to be answered on a five-point Likert scale. The questions will be given prior to and after presentation of the twitter-tweet (pre-post design). In addition, we will ask 22 questions to assess trait autonomy.

conditions.value: There will be 2 authors x 3 message-frames, varied between-participants, so 6 groups in total. Each group will be questioned twice, namely before and after the intervention (i.e., presentation of the twitter tweet).

hypothesis.value:
Self reported ratings of behavior: Does a twitter tweet with a morally framed message about social distancing during the COVID-19 pandemic affect recipients more than a message with an authoritarian framing, and both more than one without any reasoning (i.e., control condition)? We expect the authoritarian framing to be most effective, followed by the moral framing and we expect the control group to be least effective.

Does the effect of the message depend on the leadership status of the person who tweeted the message? We expect the effect to be larger when tweeted by a person with high as compared to low leadership status. Do both these effects correlate with self-reported trait autonomy of the recipient? We expect a negative correlation between the effects of the tweet (pre-post treatment difference) and self-reported trait autonomy. We further expect that authoritarian message framing and higher leadership status will both increase this negative correlation.

In direct evaluations of effectiveness of the messages: We expect the degree to which the authoritarian message is preferred over the moral message frame to correlate negatively with self-reported autonomy.

attributes.title: COVID-19 & Discrimination
attributes.description:
According to Bushman (2020), words matter, especially the words we use to describe a deadly virus. Calling COVID-19 the "Chinese virus" is a disturbing example of classical conditioning theory, which was discovered by Ivan Pavlov (1849-1936). Pavlov won a Nobel Prize in 1904 for his research on the role of saliva in digestion, but that is not what he is most famous for. Pavlov was studying digestion in dogs, and he noticed that the dogs started salivating at the mere sight of the food pail. Pavlov tested whether other stimuli (e.g., hearing the sound of a bell) could also be associated with food, and found similar effects. Based on his findings, Pavlov developed classical condition theory.

Classical conditioning theory begins with the premise that an unconditioned stimulus (e.g., food) will produce an unconditioned response (salivation). The neutral stimulus (e.g., the sight of a food pail, sound of a bell) initially does not produce any response. Through repeated pairing, however, the neutral stimulus becomes a conditioned stimulus, which can produce the same response as the unconditioned stimulus, called a conditioned response.

In this example, the unconditioned stimulus is the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), which produces the unconditioned response of negative feelings (e.g., fear, panic). The neutral stimulus is China. But repeatedly pairing China with the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) by calling it the "Chinese virus" may make China a conditioned stimulus. The net result is that calling coronavirus disease (COVID-19) the "Chinese virus" can produce negative feelings toward people from China and other East Asian countries.

q1.value: Brad J. Bushman, Sophie Kjaervik , Lanier Frush Holt

q2.value: It is expected that those who read the article referring to the coronavirus as the "Chinese virus" will have more negative attitudes towards Chinese- and Asian-Americans than those who read the article referring to the virus as "COVID-19".

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The research design will be a 2-group survey-experiment. Participants will be randomly assigned to read a news article that describes the coronavirus as either “COVID-19” or  the “Chinese virus” .

After reading the article, the following outcomes will be measured.
1. Participants will rate their feelings about different Americans on a scale of 0-100 on a Feelings Thermometer (i.e., African-Americans, Arab-Americans, Asian-Americans, Chinese-Americans, European-Americans, Hispanic-Americans, Native-Americans).
2. A more nuanced version of the Social Distance scale (iScore) will be used to gauge participants’ preferences about Chinese-Americans (Mather, Jones, & Moats, 2017)
3. The Anti-Asian Stereotype scale will be used to measure participants’ attitudes regarding stereotypes about Asian people (Lin, Kwan, Cheung, & Fiske, 2005).
4. The Attitudes Towards Asians Scale will be used to measure attitudes about Asian people (Ho & Jackson, 2001)
5. Three author generated items:
     (1) “It is okay to ask someone of Asian descent where they are really from.”
     (2) “It is okay to tell someone of Asian descent that they speak English very well.”
     (3)  “It is okay to ask someone of Asian descent what their real name is.”
6. Participants will indicate whether they agree with this statement” “China is responsible for the current global pandemic” (1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree)

Possible moderators/covariates include:
1. Age
2. Gender
3. Race
4. Political affiliation (Republican, Democrat, Independent, Other)
5. Political ideology (liberal to conservative on a 7-point scale).

References:
Ho, C., & Jackson, J. W. (2001). Attitude toward Asian Americans: Theory and measurement. Journal of Applied Social Psychology, 31(8), 1553-1581.

Lin, M. H., Kwan, V. S., Cheung, A., & Fiske, S. T. (2005). Stereotype content model explains prejudice for an envied outgroup: Scale of anti-Asian American stereotypes. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 31(1), 34-47.

Mather, D. M., Jones, S. W., & Moats, S. (2017). Improving upon Bogardus: Creating a more sensitive and dynamic Social Distance Scale. Survey Practice, 10(4), 1-10.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: The survey-experiment is currently in a "soft launch" stage. Preliminary data is being collected by a research firm (Dynata). The researchers have not downloaded or accessed this data as it is being collected. Furthermore, the "soft launch" only collects approximately 10% of the required sample size. Data will not be analyzed. We will only check the reliability of the scales.

question.value: Data will be collected by a research firm (Dynata); they will conduct recruitment using their online panels. Eligibility will be determined by Dynata, as well. We are seeking a nationally representative sample of American adults in terms of age and race, who do not identify as Asian-Americans. Participants will be paid by Dynata when they submit the survey.

q11.value: This study requires 568 total participants, 284 (142 men, 142 women) per group.

q12.value: The sample size of 568 will allow us to detect an effect size d = 0.25 at the .05 significance level with power = 80. Terms such as significant, important, notable, and consequential are typically reserved for effects at least d = 0.25 (Promising Practices Network, 2014). We want to have enough power to detect an effect this size (i.e., d = 0.25). We are requesting ten times the amount required to account for invalid data, bringing the total number of participants to 5680 (2840 men, 2840 women).

question.value: This survey experiment has one manipulated variable. Participants are randomly assigned to read a fabricated news article about the coronavirus, in which the virus is called COVID-19 or the "Chinese virus."

Participants will rate their feelings about different types of Americans using the Feelings Thermometer (0=Cold/negative-100=warm/positive).

Participants will rate their attitudes about Chinese-Americans using the iScore Social Distance Scale (1=Strongly Disagree-5=Strongly Agree).

Participants will rate their opinions about Asian-Americans use the Anti-Asian Stereotypes Scale 
(1=Strongly Disagree-5=Strongly Agree).

Participants will rate their attitudes about Asian-Americans using the Attitudes Towards Asians Scale (1=Strongly Disagree-5=Strongly Agree).
Data will be analyzed using statistical models such as Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) models and multiple regression models.

q20.value: Two attention checks are placed in the survey, one in the middle and one at the end. Participants who fail these attention checks will be excluded and replaced with new participants by Dynata. Also, participants who answer the survey too quickly (i.e., in less than 20% of the median time) will also be excluded and replaced with new participants by Dynata.

q21.value: Participants cannot be forced to answer all the questions. Thus, we will analyze the data for each outcome based on the number of participants who provided responses.

q22.value: Possible moderators/covariates include participant age, gender, race, political affiliation, and political ideology.

attributes.title: Functional Brain Connectivity and Inhibition Control in Older Adults
attributes.description: I will investigate the relationship between the resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) of inhibition networks, which includes the executive network of the attentional systems (Petersen & Posner, 2012), and the salience network (Seeley et al., 2007) and behavioral measures of inhibition control. I will be conducting a secondary data analysis of approximately 200 healthy aging individuals, whose data was made available by the Alzheimer’s Disease Center at the University of Kansas Medical Center. The goal of my thesis is to examine the relationship between neuroimaging and behavioral measures of these inhibition networks. My secondary focus will be to examine how this relates to aging among an aging population. I expect to bridge the gap in literature regarding inhibition and healthy aging. The inhibition deficit hypothesis states that, “older adults are less able to suppress or ignore irrelevant thoughts and actions than young adults are” (Rey-Mermet & Gade, 2017). However, results from studies have revealed mixed results, with a meta-analysis by Rey-Mermet and Gade (2017) questioning the generalizability of the hypothesis.

comments.value: Secondary data from the Alzheimer's Disease Center registry at the University of Kansas Medical Center

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

attributes.title: Replicating Perceptual versus Judgement Effects: Influence of motivational based scenario cue positions on stimulus detection
attributes.description: A replication of Bang & Rahnev (2017), but with a psychophysics task. The criterion cues will be higher level, motivational based scenarios presented before or after the stimulus.

q1.value: Lori Barney, Lingxiu Zhang, Allison Wan, Erik Spangenberg, Logan Willans, Jan Andrews, Joshua de Leeuw

q2.value:
Traditional
H₀ - There is no change in d’ as a result of the cue timing manipulation, meaning there is no effect of perception on SDT performance. 
H₁ (directional) - We expect greater d’ in the pre-condition if there is an effect of perception on SDT performance.
H2 - There should be no effect of prime type regardless of the effect of the cue timing manipulation.
H3 - (from Bang & Rahnev) There will be a correlation between beta-pre and beta-post meaning there is no effect of perception. (Alternatively, there is no correlation between beta-pre and beta-post if there is an effect of perception)
H4 - As a manipulation check, beta should decrease in the condition that biases for false positives. Beta should increase in conditions that bias for false negatives.
**From the previous study, we have grounds to believe that there is no effect of perception on judgement.

Bayesian
If this is true, these are the expected effects
“Null” model - The d prime of trials of criterion cue before the stimulus will have no difference to d prime on trials where the criterion cue is presented after.  The true effect is exactly zero (H0 ∶ δ = 0)
If this is true, these are the expected effects
“Alternative” model - The d prime of trials of criterion cue before the stimulus will be greater than d prime on trials where the criterion cue is presented after.  This is one sided where H+ ∶ δ < 0
effect size unsure, but something other than zero

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a within-subjects design with 2 factors consisting of 2 levels each. The first factor is whether the cue occurs before or after the stimulus (pre cue vs. post cue). The second factor is whether the cue promotes false positive or false negative responses. Participants will be presented with either a pre or post cue and asked to determine whether there was a faster moving dot on the screen. A pre-cue trial consists of the prime followed by the SDT stimulus with a final screen asking participants if they saw a faster moving dot. The post-cue trial starts with the SDT stimulus followed by the prime, then the final screen where participants indicate if they saw a faster moving dot. We will record their response time and accuracy. Trials will be randomized in blocks where each block consists of 8 trials that randomize false positive and false negative primes. Each block will contain one type of cue. For example, one participant will complete 8 pre-cue trials and then 8 post-cue trials. Participants will receive an equal number of both task conditions and an equal number of primes for false positives and false negatives. Participants will complete 16 total trials. The computer program that will be used to run the experiment was made using jsPsych.

q7.value: Experiment will feature two conditions, pre and post trial cue. Within each type of trial the possible cues will include judgemental weights towards false positives and weights towards false negatives. We anticipate randomizing weights. Each participant will receive all four conditions (Pre false positive cue, pre false negative cue, post false positive cue, and post false negative cue).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Collecting data from the population of online participants from Prolific. Participants will be paid $8/hour for agreeing to participate. All participants of this pool are eligible for recruitment. Approximately 98 participants will be recruited around April 11th. Data collection will proceed until funds are exhausted, at which point analysis will begin.

q11.value: Participants will all come from the Prolific website. Our target sample size is 98 participants who complete the total task.

q12.value: Sample size limited by funds for experiment, roughly $130. Experimenters plan to take on as many participants as possible.

question.value: We manipulate the cue position of the task, either pre or post task. We have cues that prime for false positives and cues that prime for false negatives. Each participant will be exposed to both variations to control for an expected learning curve. We also manipulate if there is a dot that is moving faster than the other dots. The faster dot speed is a set value.

The single outcome variable will be the accuracy (stimulus sensitivity, d’) of the participant in correctly identifying if there is a dot moving faster than the other dots on the screen. As a manipulation check, we will analyze criterion changes for each condition (pre cue, false positive; pre cue, false negative; post cue, false positive; post cue, false negative).

We will use a two-tailed paired samples t-test between sensitivity in the pre cue condition and post cue condition. The manipulated, categorical independent variable is 'cue position' whereas the dependent variable is participant accuracy (d’). As a manipulation check, we will compare beta for each condition with 2-way repeated measures ANOVA.

q18.value: There will be no transformation of the data.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and t-test results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value: Accuracy of above 90% will be excluded, as this indicates the participant’s visual threshold was reached. Accuracy below 25% will be excluded from analysis. The full distribution of response times (all conditions combined) will be examined to determine if any outliers should be excluded.

q21.value: If a participant does not complete all four trial blocks, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q22.value: We plan to explore if there is a difference in response time between the pre and post cue groups. We do not expect there to be a difference. We will also explore the criterion pre vs. post cue correlation and the effect of prime type on d’.

q23.value:
Github = https://github.com/loganwillans/2020TopDownSDT

Reference article = Bang, J. & Rahnev, D. (2017). Stimulus expectation alters decision criterion but not sensory signal in perceptual decision making. Scientific Reports, 7(17072), p. 1-12. DOI: 10.1038/s41598-017-16885-2

Psychophysics task = Krantz, J.H. Experiencing Sensation and Perception: Chapter 2, Psychophysics, section 2.10. https://isle.hanover.edu

Participants will receive an equal number of both task conditions and an equal number of primes for false positives and false negatives. Participants will complete 16 total trials. The computer program that will be used to run the experiment was made using jsPsych.
registration_responses.q10.question: Collecting data from the population of online participants from Prolific. Participants will be paid $8/hour for agreeing to participate. All participants of this pool are eligible for recruitment. Approximately 98 participants will be recruited around April 11th. Data collection will proceed until funds are exhausted, at which point analysis will begin.
registration_responses.q14.question: We manipulate the cue position of the task, either pre or post task. We have cues that prime for false positives and cues that prime for false negatives. Each participant will be exposed to both variations to control for an expected learning curve. We also manipulate if there is a dot that is moving faster than the other dots. The faster dot speed is a set value.
registration_responses.q15.question: The single outcome variable will be the accuracy (stimulus sensitivity, d’) of the participant in correctly identifying if there is a dot moving faster than the other dots on the screen. As a manipulation check, we will analyze criterion changes for each condition (pre cue, false positive; pre cue, false negative; post cue, false positive; post cue, false negative).
registration_responses.q17.question: We will use a two-tailed paired samples t-test between sensitivity in the pre cue condition and post cue condition. The manipulated, categorical independent variable is 'cue position' whereas the dependent variable is participant accuracy (d’). As a manipulation check, we will compare beta for each condition with 2-way repeated measures ANOVA.

question5a.value: It is usually understood that people who wish to provide a better future are motivated by moral ideas. There is a difference, however, between the will to provide a better future and the belief that one can. The theory of the revolutionary mentality argues that throughout history there is a clearly identifiable and continuous state of mind present in some individuals called the revolutionary mentality, in which one finds oneself apt to reshape society by political means (de Carvalho, 2007). As such, the individuals with this mentality find themselves as the carrier of the better future, representing ideals that are above any judgement by those who do not hold them. The result of this state of mind is a series of mental inversions, being the one addressed in this research the inversion of morality. This specific inversion refers to the idea that means justify the ends, that is, if one finds oneself apt of achieving the utopian future, every measure taken for it is automatically justified as being good in nature. The hypothesis that being a change activist is positively correlated with anger comes from the predictions of the revolutionary mentality theory, that is, anger is a psychological state clearly related to immorality and change activists face much higher states of revolutionary mentality. The second hypothesis - that social influencers and organizations will be negatively correlated to anger - originated from the notion that when one has a lot of influence, it is common for one to hide negative aspects. For example, politicians and NGO's representatives will show their negative side on public less than an "unknown" person would.

question6a.value: The theory predicts a positive relationship between anger and change activist accounts. It can be the case that activism is causing anger or that anger is causing activism. For the purposes of the theory, causality does not matter: the theory argues that there is a positive relationship, not aiming to explain its origins. This study is correlational, and therefore this study aims to find an effect and not argue for causality.

question2c.value:
Hypothesis 1.
To test this hypothesis, two techniques will be used. First, a simple linear regression model regressing anger on type of account. Second, gender will be added to the regression model. The reason for testing separately is that institutions do not have a gender, and therefore will be excluded from the second model.

question1c.value:
1. Anger. It will measure the level of anger present in the tweets as retrieved from analyzewords.com. Numerical variable, takes the value of any integer from 0 to 100: the closer to 100, the higher the level of anger present in the tweets. 

2. Activist anger. It is the variable anger but only with the values respective to activist accounts.

3. Christian anger. It is the variable anger but only with the values respective to Christian accounts.

4. Type of Account. It will indicate the type of account. Categorical 2-level variable: 
Level 1: activist - takes the numerical value of 1; 
Level 2: Christian - takes the numerical value of -1. 

5. Influencer. It will indicate if the account user is an influencer or an "average citizen". Categorical 2-level variable: 
Level 1: influencer - takes the numerical value of 1; 
Level 2: average citizen - takes the numerical value of -1. 

6. Institution. It will indicate if the account user is an institution or an "average citizen". Categorical 2-level variable: 
Level 1: institution - takes the numerical value of 1; 
Level 2: average citizen - takes the numerical value of -1.

question2c.value: Three techniques will be used. First, a multiple linear regression model will be used to regress anger on type of account, influencer, and institution. Second, a multiple linear regression will be used to regress activist anger on influencer and institution, in order to find the specific effect that influence and institution have specifically on activist accounts. Third, a multiple linear regression will be used to regress Christian anger on influencer and institution, in order to find the specific effect that influence and institution have specifically on Christian accounts.

attributes.title: Microablative Fractional Radiofrequency on vaginal health, microbiota, and cellularity of postmenopausal women: Protocol of randomized controlled trial
attributes.description: The is a protocol of randomized, controlled clinical intervention trial with an open-label design comparing treatment of microablative fractional radiofrequency (MAFRF), with vaginal estrogens as well as no treatment.

q1.value: Ana  Katherine Gonçalves, Ayane Cristine Alves Sarmento, Fabíola Sephora Fernandes, Janaína Cristiana de Oliveira Crispim

q2.value: Hypothesis 1: MAFRF treatment is safe and effective, (H0: MAFRF is not safe and effective) and Hypothesis 2: MAFRF treatment is as safe and effective as standard vaginal estrogen treatment (H0: MAFRF is not as safe and effective as estrogen treatment).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: The study is a randomized, controlled clinical intervention trial with an open-label design comparing treatment with MAFRF with vaginal estrogens as well as no treatment.

q7.value: Eligible participants who provide written consent will be randomized into the Software Research Randomizer® program. In order to ensure allocation concealment, an offsite randomization schedule will be used. The randomization schedule will be prepared in advance by a researcher at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte (UFRN), who will have no contact with any participants throughout the trial and will not be involved in the recruitment, screening, assessment, enrollment or treatment process.  To enroll a participant, the primary researcher will email the consenting participant's name to the researcher at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte (UFRN). These details will be entered into the allocation spreadsheet, and the next treatment allocation and participant identiﬁcation number with be emailed directly to the treatment.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
Population
Participant recruitment is currently ongoing at a gynecological Unit of a public university hospital. Patients who fulfill the inclusion criteria and who sign the free and informed consent forms will enter the screening period. Patients who meet the exclusion criteria will be excluded before randomization. The recruitment duration will last for 24 months, from March 2020 to March 2022.

Eligibility criteria
The study will include healthy postmenopausal women (55 to 65 years old, with whom at least 12 months have passed since last menstrual period or bilateral oophorectomy), who are still sexually active, with GSM, plasma gonadotropin and presenting serum estradiol levels in the postmenopausal range (FSH >40 U/L; estradiol <25 pg/ml) as well as negative Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for cervical cancer precursor cells. Women who have used any form of hormonal (systemic or local) therapy in the last six months, lubricants or vaginal moisturizers in the past month, suffering from active genital infections and any disease that would interfere following the protocol will be excluded. Fig1 shows the study flow.

Questionnaire  
In the first interview, the women will answer a standardized questionnaire with information on demographic characteristics including age, time since menopause, skin color, smoking habit, parity, schooling, and socioeconomic classification.

q11.value: The sample size was calculated according to the results of a pilot study, where data came from 55 volunteers - with a 90% power at a two-tailed significance level of 5%. We also assume a 20% increase in the sample size to consider potential dropout. The calculated number of participants for each arm is 66 for a final sample of 198.

question.value:
Six relevant time points will be considered for the evaluation of treatment results based on a previous study [8] baseline (T0), 30 days after the first application (T1), seven days after second application (T2), 30 days after second application (T3), seven days after last application (T4) and 30 days after the previous radiofrequency application (T5). Primary outcomes will be vaginal microbiota, vaginal pH, and cell maturation. Vaginal smears will be obtained, which will be subsequently stained according to the standard Gram staining procedure for the classification of vaginal flora, following the criteria of Spiegel [11]. Vaginal pH can be measured in different ways. Most studies describe the use of a pH indicator stripe on the lateral wall of the vagina [12,13]. Moreover, vaginal pH measurement is considered useful, practical, and inexpensive. For vaginal pH determination, the pH indicator strips will be applied against the vaginal wall. The pH will be measured by the gynecologist responsible for the procedure. For analysis of vaginal cytology, vaginal smears will be obtained from the upper third of the right lateral vaginal wall, at predefined times. The material collected from the vaginal sac will be distributed on the blade, adequately identified and fixed, and subsequently stained by the Papanicolaou technique for determining the degree of maturation of the vaginal epithelium by the Frost Index [14,15]. These will be analyzed in the laboratory by two cytologists who are unaware of the women's identity and at what times of treatment the samples were obtained. 
          Secondary outcomes include the Vaginal Health Index (VHI). The vaginal health score consists of the clinical analysis during the specular examination of five parameters (elasticity, fluid volume, pH, the integrity of the epithelium, and humidity), and is graded from 1 to 5. The sum of the values of the parameters evaluated results in the total vaginal health score. When the overall rating is less than 15, the vaginal mucosa is considered atrophic [16].

The characterization of the vaginal ecosystem by Spiegel criteria: Type 1 (predominance of at least 85% lactobacilli), type 2 (balance between 50% lactobacilli and coccoid flora), and type 3 (0%, almost complete absence of lactobacilli with the presence of cocoidal flora) [11].
Vaginal pH: pH less than or equal to 5.0 would be indicative of normal vaginal trophism, and a pH higher than five would be indicative of vaginal atrophy [1].
Vaginal maturation (Frost index): The percentage count of each cell type will be made, that is, parabasal, intermediate, and superficial cells (P / I / S), evidenced by a decrease in parabasal cells and an increase in the proportion of superficial cells [16].
The vaginal Health Index (VHI): The scale of 1 (most inferior) to 5 (best): When the overall score is less than 15, the vaginal mucosa is considered atrophic [12].

Data will be analyzed on an intention-to-treat basis, including all participants enrolled in each group. Epidemiological and clinical characteristics data will be analyzed using the chi-squared test, nonparametric Kruskal–Wallis test, and analysis of variance. Analysis of percentages in each group compared with the control group for vaginal maturation index, pH, vaginal health, and presence of lactobacilli will be performed with the chi-squared and Fisher’s exact tests. P < 0.05 will be considered statistically significant. The software that will be used is SPSS for Windows, version 20.0 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA).

attributes.title: Social Reinforcement of Moral Outrage in Online Social Networks
attributes.description: Testing in a behavioral paradigm that differences in the extent to which people rely on norms vs reward learning when each are available for different types of message content.

q1.value: William J. Brady, Killian McLoughlin, Tuan Nguyen, Molly Crockett

q2.value:
In Study 1, we showed that people rely on two different types of learning depending on what information they have: reinforcement learning (trial-and-error learning) when they must rely on (likes/shares) to learn from or (2) efficient learning based on the communication of an expected behavior (inferring social norms) when such information can guide them.

In this study, we hypothesize that when both types of information are available, people will rely on norm learning relatively more for outrage expression than for neutral expressions. We predict this pattern of results because outrage expression is tied to social information and thus is likely more sensitive to norm information when it is available.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In this study, participants are randomly assigned to one of two conditions: "View Outrage Norm", "View Neutral Norm" condition. Participants view 12 tweets that were ostensibly posted by the new social network they will be embedded in for the learning task. 

In the View Outrage Norm condition, participants will be exposed to tweets, 75% of which contain outrage, where the outrage tweets also contain higher social feedback values than the 25% neutral tweets. Participants in this condition will then complete a social reinforcement task where they view pairs of tweets (1 outrage, 1 neutral) and choose which tweet to send to their network with the goal of maximizing their total likes. Stimulus pairs are randomized, reward trajectories have the following structure: 80% of the time an outrage tweets selection leads to the delivery of likes drawing from a distribution with a larger mean (the "high feedback distribution). 20% of the time choosing an outrage tweet will deliver a feedback amount drawn from the "low feedback" distribution. The opposite is true for neutral tweets. This design adds noise to the learning to ensure it is not too easy.

In the View Neutral Norm condition, participants will be exposed to 100% non-outrage tweets, with higher social feedback values being randomly assigned to the tweets. Participants in this condition will then complete a social reinforcement task where they view pairs of tweets (1 outrage, 1 neutral) and choose which tweet to send to their network with the goal of maximizing their total likes. Stimulus pairs are randomized, reward trajectories have the following structure: 80% of the time a neutral tweet selection leads to the delivery of likes drawing from a distribution with a larger mean (the "high feedback distribution). 20% of the time choosing a neutral tweet will deliver a feedback amount drawn from the "low feedback" distribution. The opposite is true for outrage tweets. This design adds noise to the learning to ensure it is not too easy.

We will recruit participants via Prolific, and we will recruit only liberal-learning participants because our tweet stim only express political views aligned with liberal values.

We will also recruit social media users, since our goal is to simulate a Twitter environment in our task to support the analyses we performed in our Twitter sample.

q11.value: We will collect 120 participants and each participants will have 30 observations (trials).

q12.value: We will collect 120 participants, which was determined by the required sample size to achieve 95% power to detect differences in slope of the learning effect over trials among the conditions. We used SIMR, an R package for power analysis for GLMMs.

question.value: We manipulate whether participants view an outrage norm network or view a neutral norm network, and this manipulation also determines what reward structure they see in the learning task (outrage condition = outrage tweets rewarded more, neutral condition = neutral tweets rewarded more).
We will measure the binary choice of whether to "share" an outrage message or a neutral message for each of the 30 trials.
We will use a generalized linear mixed model with a log link function to model participants' selection of outrage on a trial-by-trial basis across the learning task.

We will remove participants who are not liberal-learning according to self-report measure of ideology.

We will remove participants who did not spend more than 30 seconds viewing the tweets in their network during the norm manipulation.

We will remove participants who exhibit homogeneous choices across all 30 trials of the learning task. In other words, if a participants just clicked the tweet to the left for all trials, or clicked the tweet to the right for all trials.

q21.value: Participants who do not complete the full learning task will be removed.

q22.value: We will report any analyzes not preregistered in this form as exploratory. This may include examining if learning is moderated by self-reported social media use.

registration_responses.q1: William J. Brady, Killian McLoughlin, Tuan Nguyen, Molly Crockett
registration_responses.q2:
In Study 1, we showed that people rely on two different types of learning depending on what information they have: reinforcement learning (trial-and-error learning) when they must rely on (likes/shares) to learn from or (2) efficient learning based on the communication of an expected behavior (inferring social norms) when such information can guide them.

In this study, we hypothesize that when both types of information are available, people will rely on norm learning relatively more for outrage expression than for neutral expressions. We predict this pattern of results because outrage expression is tied to social information and thus is likely more sensitive to norm information when it is available.

attributes.title: Fancy Tastes 3: An Experimental Test of Food as a Social Status Cue
attributes.description: The following study will test whether food can serve as a cue for one's social status

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Fancy Tastes 3: An Experimental Test of Food as a Social Status Cue

other.value:
Upon pretesting our materials, we decided to add a “no food” control to see whether these effects are driven by individuals boosting the perceived status of healthy eaters or degrading the perceived status of unhealthy eaters relative to control. Thus, we will make no directional hypothesis regarding the “no food” control group.

In addition to the covariates above, we will also run exploratory analyses controlling for dieting and restrained eating status. We do not expect this to change the outcome of our hypotheses

sample.value: 480 participants will be required to detect a small-to-medium effect size with power set at 0.95. Due to limitations of our subject pool, we will only be able to collect data from 300 participants. We can detect a small effect size (d = 0.23) with power set at 0.95.

analyses.value:
Hypotheses 1 & 2: I will run an ANCOVA to test whether an unhealthy eater's subjective (objective) social status is significantly lower than a healthy eater's social status. In line with past work, I will control for age, race/ethnicity, gender, parental income, parental education, and political affiliation (Kraus & Keltner, 2013; Kraus et al., 2017; Tan & Kraus, 2015).

Hypotheses 3: I will run an ANCOVA to test whether an unhealthy eater's is perceived to have significantly less competence than a healthy eater. In line with past work, I will control for age, race/ethnicity, gender, parental income, parental education, and political affiliation (Kraus & Keltner, 2013; Kraus et al., 2017; Tan & Kraus, 2015).

Hypotheses 4: I will run an ANCOVA to test whether an unhealthy eater is perceived to be have significantly more warmth than a healthy eater. In line with past work, I will control for age, race/ethnicity, gender, parental income, parental education, and political affiliation (Kraus & Keltner, 2013; Kraus et al., 2017; Tan & Kraus, 2015).

outliers.value: Outliers in any variable of interest (3 SD from the mean) will be Windsorized, but we will also conduct analyses with the full dataset.

dependent.value:
Subjective social status: Subjective social status will be measured with the MacArthur Subjective Social Status Community Ladder (Adler & Epel, 2000). Participants will be asked to estimate the healthy (unhealthy/no food control) eater's community social status. Higher scores on the ladder represent higher perceived status in the community. 

Objective social status: Objective social status will be measured using a VAS scale, anchored from “$10,000 or less” to “$200,000 or more”. Participants will be asked to estimate the healthy (unhealthy/no food control) eater's parental income.

Competence: After reading a short biography about a person named Alex, participants will be asked to rate how incompetent/competent and incapable/capable Alex is, using a 7-point Likert scale.

Warmth: Participants will be asked to rate how unfriendly/friendly and cold/warm they believe Alex is, using a 7-point Likert scale.

conditions.value: Three: Unhealthy eater, healthy eater, no food control

hypothesis.value:
Hypothesis 1: Participants will rate an unhealthy eater as having a significantly lower subjective social status than a healthy eater.

Hypothesis 2: Participants will rate an unhealthy eater as having a significantly lower objective social status than a healthy eater.

Hypothesis 3: Participants will rate an unhealthy eater as possessing significantly less competence than a healthy eater.

Hypothesis 4: Participants will rate an unhealthy eater as possessing significantly more warmth than a healthy eater.
